title: ASX to slip, S&P 500 edges down
text:
Today's agenda

Local: NZ trade balance September

Overseas data: Singapore and Malaysia inflation September; Euro zone consumer confidence October; US FHFA house prices August

Market highlights

ASX futures down 3 points to 6644 near 6.30am AEDT

AUD -0.2% to 68.58 US cents

On Wall St near 3.35pm: Dow +0.2% S &P 500 -0.2% Nasdaq -0.4%

In New York: BHP +0.7% Rio +1% Atlassian -5.4%

In Europe: Stoxx 50 +0.1% FTSE +0.7% CAC +0.2% DAX +0.1%

Nikkei 225 futures +0.5% Hang Seng futures +0.3%

Spot gold flat at $US1484.75 an ounce at 1pm New York time

Brent crude +0.9% to $US59.51 a barrel

US oil +1.6% to $US54.15 a barrel

Iron ore +1.5% to $US86.68 a tonne

Dalian iron ore +2% to 625.5 yuan

Comex copper -0.4% to $US263.60 a pound

2-year yield: US 1.61% Australia

5-year yield: US 1.60% Australia

10-year yield: US 1.77% Australia 1.16% Germany 0.37%

10-year US/Australia yield gap near 4am AEDT: 63 basis points

From today's Financial Review

Industry groups split on 12pc super guarantee: The nation's biggest employer groups are openly contemplating another freeze in the super guarantee following the appointment of an expert panel to review the retirement income system.

Advertisement

Bond market rethink points to growth recovery: The sharp improvement in sentiment in the bond market suggests the global and domestic economies have turned a corner, but some managers say it's an illusion.

WAAAX wobble has investors wondering if this time is different: A rotation from growth to value is a welcome change for the Australian market, but nobody can say with any confidence if it lasts.

United States

The S &P 500 and Dow Jones indexes rose on Tuesday, lifted by upbeat corporate earnings reports that eased concerns over the fallout from the U.S.-China trade war, but a decline in shares of Facebook hurt the Nasdaq.

The benchmark S &P 500 index, which continued to hold above 3,000 points, was within striking distance of a record high hit in July, with Biogen's 26.5% surge also boosting the index. The drugmaker announced a surprise plan to file for U.S. regulatory approval for its Alzheimer's treatment.

"I think the fact that we are encroaching on record territory in the face of all these issues speaks to the resilience of the domestic economy and more importantly the companies in the U.S.," said Mike Loewengart, vice president, investment strategy at E*TRADE Financial.

The wider healthcare index clocked the biggest increase among the major S &P 500 sectors.

Strong corporate earnings since last week have provided some respite to equity markets, which were rattled over the past few months by geopolitical worries and a slowing global economy.

Advertisement

Of the 98 S &P 500 companies that have reported results so far, over 80% of them topped Street estimates. Still, analysts project the first earnings contraction since 2016.

"So we have got dueling forces between what we are seeing on earnings offset some moderating economic indicators and then we overlay all that with the trade landscape and that's what's driving markets today," Loewengart added.

Data showed U.S. home sales fell more than expected in September as the market continues to struggle with a dearth of properties for sale, especially for cheaper homes.

Europe

Time's up: MPs set for vote on fate of October 31 Brexit: If MPs back the British PM, he stands a chance of delivering Brexit next week. If not, a delay - and probably an election - looks inevitable.

London's FTSE 100 was lifted by export-focused stocks on Tuesday as uncertainty over whether British lawmakers would support the government's Brexit deal took its toll on the pound.

The FTSE 100 added 0.7%, with BP and Shell both gaining more than 2% and Asia-focussed HSBC also rising after China signalled progress in trade talks with the United States.

Other standouts in the index, whose components book most of their earnings abroad, were AstraZeneca and BAT , while Durex condom maker Reckitt pared losses despite cutting its sales view for the second time this year.

Advertisement

However, the domestically-focussed FTSE 250, which has gained more than 4% since September on hopes of a smooth end to the Brexit process, slipped 0.5%.

British Prime Minister Boris Johnson told parliament that if it delayed his legislation to leave the European Union he would abandon his attempt to ratify the deal and push for an election instead, threatening further political turmoil.

"The optimism of last week about the prospect of a deal being approved has been replaced by a sense of fatigue," David Madden at CMC Markets said.

Asia

Hong Kong stocks closed higher on Tuesday as investors cheered the prospects of a Sino-U.S. trade deal, though losses in tech and real estate stocks capped gains.

The Hang Seng index rose 0.2%, to 26,786.20, while the China Enterprises Index lost 0.2%, to 10,526.86.

China and the United States have achieved some progress in their trade talks, Vice Foreign Minister Le Yucheng said on Tuesday, and any problem could be resolved as long as both sides respected each other.

China stocks recouped earlier losses to end higher on Tuesday, bolstered by tech firms as investors cheered their solid earnings as Beijing seeks to support the sector amid a bruising trade war.

Advertisement

The blue-chip CSI300 index rose 0.4%, to 3895.88, while the Shanghai Composite Index added 0.5% to 2954.38.

Currencies

Sterling pulled back from 5-1/2-month highs on Tuesday as markets priced in some uncertainty before crucial parliament votes on the government's Brexit withdrawal bill that will determine whether Britain can leave the European Union on Oct. 31.

It had earlier slipped as much as 0.5% after the BBC quoted a government source as saying the UK government planned to abandon Brexit legislation and hold an election by Christmas if parliament voted against the motion to rush the Brexit bill through in three days.

UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson then echoed this ultimatum to lawmakers when opening a debate before the vote.

Having touched the day's low of $1.2889, the pound then recovered to around $1.2953. Versus the euro, sterling was little changed at 86.11 pence.

"(The BBC report) has made the market wary that it could see an increase in uncertainty if we head towards an election," Lee Hardman, a strategist at MUFG, said.

He described it as a knee-jerk reaction, given the pound's recent sharp rally.

Advertisement

The prime minister would need to win a vote to trigger an early election because one is not scheduled until 2022. That looks unlikely given he lacks a majority in the House of Commons.

Commodities

BHP and Rio are riding Chile's subway to chaos: This might not be the Latin Spring but it should be a wake-up call for the risk-profilers that guide the major shareholders of BHP and Rio Tinto.

Eureka! Rio may produce lithium from borates waste: Rio Tinto wants to make treasure, in the form of lithium, from its borates mining trash, adding to the woes of incumbent producers such as Orocobre.

Solar households to face hit from zero prices: Homes that don't have regulated solar feed-in tariffs are likely to be affected as retailers reduce the price they offer for power pumped into the grid.

Australian sharemarket

OpenLearning to list on ASX, beef up board: Adam Brimo started MOOCs platform OpenLearning in Sydney in 2012, now he's listing it on the ASX with a high-powered board.

Australian shares advanced on Tuesday but gains were capped as encouraging signs that interest rates are continuing to support the housing market were partly offset by gloomy corporate commentary on consumer spending.

Advertisement

The S &P/ASX 200 index rose 19 points, or 0.3 per cent, to 6672.20.

Street Talk

PropertyGuru IPO covered at the bottom of the range: book message

Engie readies co-investor search for Aus renewables portfolio

Elanor Commercial IPO makes maiden investor pitch
description: Australian shares are poised to open lower, following modest losses in late trading on Wall Street.
